This information pertains to the Analysis of Algorithms course (ADC402).
What are the objectives of ADC402?

The objectives of ADC402 include providing mathematical approaches for analyzing algorithms, understanding and solving problems using various algorithmic approaches, and analyzing algorithms using different methods.
How is the term work evaluated for ADC402?
Term work for ADC402 involves assessments through tutorials, assignments, viva, and mini projects based on the syllabus.
What is the internal assessment structure for ADC402?

Internal assessment includes one mid-term test of 20 marks and continuous assessment of 20 marks. Continuous assessment involves various rubrics such as certificate courses, content beyond syllabus presentation, proof of concept, mini projects, extra experiments, competitive programming events, group discussions, and gate-based assignments.
What is the structure of the end-semester theory examination for ADC402?

The end-semester theory examination for ADC402 consists of a question paper of 60 marks with five questions, each carrying equal weightage of 20 marks. Students need to solve any three out of the five questions.

This information pertains to the Analysis of Algorithms Lab (ADL401).
What are the objectives of ADL401?

The objectives include introducing methods of designing and analyzing algorithms, designing and implementing efficient algorithms for specific applications, strengthening the ability to identify and apply suitable algorithms for real-world problems, and analyzing worst-case running time of algorithms.
What are the lab outcomes for ADL401?

At the end of the course, students will be able to implement algorithms using different approaches, analyze the complexities of various algorithms, and compare the complexity of algorithms for specific problems.
Can you provide some suggested practical experiments for ADL401?

Sure! Here are some suggested experiments for ADL401: 1. Introduction: Selection sort, Insertion sort, Bubble sort, Shell sort, Heap sort, Merge sort, Quick sort, Radix sort, Counting sort, Bucket sort 2. Divide and Conquer Approach: Finding Minimum and Maximum, Merge sort, Quick sort, Binary search, Closest pair of points, Strassen's algorithm, Karatsuba algorithm, Fast Fourier Transform, Closest pair of points in 3D 3. Greedy Method Approach: Single source shortest path (Dijkstra), Fractional Knapsack problem, Job sequencing with deadlines, Minimum cost spanning trees (Kruskal and Prim’s algorithm), Huffman coding, Task scheduling, Activity selection problem, Fractional knapsack problem with multiple occurrences 4. Dynamic Programming Approach: Single source shortest path (Bellman Ford), All pair shortest path (Floyd Warshall), 0/1 knapsack, Travelling salesperson problem, Longest common subsequence, Matrix chain multiplication, Optimal binary search trees, Longest increasing subsequence, Coin change problem, Edit distance 5. Backtracking and Branch and bound: N-queen problem, Sum of subsets, Graph coloring, Hamiltonian cycle, Subset sum problem, Knight's tour, Rat in a maze, Sudoku solver, Word break problem 6. String Matching Algorithms: The Naïve string-matching Algorithms, The Rabin Karp algorithm, The Knuth-Morris-Pratt algorithm, Boyer-Moore algorithm, Finite automaton algorithm, Shift-or algorithm, Aho-Corasick algorithm, Commentz-Walter algorithm
This information pertains to the Database Management System Lab (ADL402).
What are the objectives of the Database Management System Lab?

The objectives of ADL402 are to explore the design and development of the relational model, present SQL and procedural interfaces to SQL comprehensively, and introduce the concepts of transactions and transaction processing.
What are the lab outcomes for the Database Management System Lab?

At the end of the course, students will be able to design ER/EER diagrams and convert them to relational models for real-world applications, apply DDL, DML, DCL, and TCL commands, write simple and complex queries, use PL/SQL constructs, and demonstrate the concept of concurrent transactions execution and frontend-backend connectivity.
Can you provide a suggested list of experiments for the Database Management System Lab?

Certainly! Here is a suggested list of experiments for ADL402: 1. Identify the case study and detail statement of the problem. Design an Entity-Relationship (ER)/Extended Entity-Relationship (EER) Model. 2. Mapping ER/EER to Relational schema model. 3. Create a database using Data Definition Language (DDL) and apply integrity constraints for the specified system. 4. Apply DML Commands for the specified system. 5. Perform Simple queries, string manipulation operations, and aggregate functions. 6. Implement various Join operations. 7. Perform Nested and Complex queries. 8. Perform DCL and TCL commands. 9. Implement procedures and functions. 10. Implementation of Views and Triggers. 11. Demonstrate Database connectivity. 12. Implementation and demonstration of Transaction and Concurrency control techniques using locks. 13. Implementing database replication. 14. Working with distributed databases. 15. Implementing data warehousing concepts. 16. Implementing database security measures. 17. Working with XML and JSON data in databases. 18. Implementing database performance tuning strategies. 19. Working with NoSQL databases. 20. Implementing advanced SQL queries and optimization techniques.
How is the term work evaluated for the Database Management System Lab?
The term work for ADL402 consists of 8 to 12 experiments, and the final certification is based on satisfactory performance in laboratory work and meeting the minimum passing marks.
What is the evaluation exam structure for the Database Management System Lab?
The evaluation exam includes a practical exam based on the syllabus of ADL402, covering the concepts learned in both the lab and lecture components of the course.
This information pertains to the Internet of Things Lab (ADL403).
What are the objectives of the Internet of Things Lab?

The objectives of ADL403 include learning different types of sensors, designing problem solutions using sensors, studying basic concepts of programming/sensors/emulators, designing and implementing mini projects for project-based learning, building and testing mini projects successfully, and improving team building, communication, and management skills.
What are the lab outcomes for the Internet of Things Lab?

At the end of the course, learners will be able to identify requirements for real-world problems, conduct surveys of available literature, study and enhance software/hardware skills, demonstrate and build projects successfully, report and present findings, and work in teams and manage research studies.
Can you provide some suggested experiments for the Internet of Things Lab?

Of course! Here are some suggested experiments for ADL403: 1. Identify the Hardware (Motes from different Motes families) & sensor configuration and software requirements for the mini project problem statement. 2. Design your own circuit board using multiple sensors etc. 3. Installation, configure and manage your sensors in such a way so that they can communicate with each other. 4. Work with the operating system, emulator like contiki cooja and do coding for input devices on sensors. 5. Create an interface using Mobile/Web to publish or remotely access the data on the Internet. 6. Developing IoT applications using MQTT protocol. 7. Implementing IoT security measures. 8. Building IoT systems with edge computing capabilities. 9. Integrating IoT devices with cloud platforms. 10. Developing IoT analytics solutions. 11. Implementing machine learning algorithms on IoT data. 12. Deploying and managing IoT infrastructure. 13. Working with industrial IoT protocols and standards. 14. Implementing IoT-based automation systems. 15. Developing IoT solutions for smart cities
How is the term work evaluated for the Internet of Things Lab?
The term work for ADL403 consists of 5 Assignment/Activity/Experiments, and the final certification is based on satisfactory performance in laboratory work and meeting the minimum passing marks.
What is the evaluation exam structure for the Internet of Things Lab?
The evaluation exam includes a practical exam based on the syllabus of ADL403, covering the concepts learned in both the lab and lecture components of the course.
This information pertains to the Python Programming Lab (ADL404).
What are the objectives of the Python Programming Lab?

The objectives of ADL404 include learning basics of Python programming, exploring decision making, data structure, and functions in Python, understanding object-oriented programming using Python, and working with web frameworks for developing Python-based applications.
What are the lab outcomes for the Python Programming Lab?

At the end of the course, students will be able to understand basic concepts in Python, explore contents of files, directories, and text processing with Python, develop programs for data structures using built-in functions in Python, explore Django web framework for developing Python-based web applications, and understand multithreading concepts using Python.
Can you provide some suggested experiments for the Python Programming Lab?

Sure! Here are some suggested experiments for ADL404: 1. Exploring basics of Python like data types (strings, lists, arrays, dictionaries, sets, tuples) and control statements. 2. Creating functions, classes, and objects using Python. Demonstrate exception handling and inheritance. 3. Exploring files and directories. 4. Creating GUI with Python containing widgets such as labels, textboxes, radio buttons, checkboxes, and custom dialog boxes. 5. Menu-driven program for data structure using built-in functions for linked lists, stacks, and queues. 6. Program to demonstrate CRUD (create, read, update, and delete) operations on a database (SQLite/MySQL) using Python. 7. Creation of a simple socket for basic information exchange between server and client. 8. Creating a web application using Django web framework to demonstrate the functionality of user login and registration (also validating user details using regular expressions). 9. Programs on threading using Python. 10. Exploring basics of NumPy methods. 11. Program to demonstrate the use of NumPy: Array objects. 12. Program to demonstrate data series and data frames using Pandas. 13. Program to send email and read the content of a URL.
How is the term work evaluated for the Python Programming Lab?
The term work for ADL404 consists of 8 to 12 experiments, and the final certification is based on satisfactory performance in laboratory work and meeting the minimum passing marks.
What is the evaluation exam structure for the Python Programming Lab?
The evaluation exam includes a practical exam based on the syllabus of ADL404, covering the concepts learned in both the lab and lecture components of the course.

At the end of the course, students will be able to understand cross-platform mobile application development using the Flutter framework, design and develop interactive Flutter apps using widgets, layouts, gestures, and animation, and analyze and build production-ready Flutter apps by incorporating backend services and deploying on Android/iOS.

What are the objectives of ADC501?
The objectives of ADC501, Cloud Computing, include understanding cloud computing techniques, virtualization levels, cloud service providers, cloud implementation, and security risks.
What are the course outcomes of ADC501?

After completing ADC501, students will be able to differentiate between different cloud computing techniques, understand virtualization concepts, compare various cloud computing providers, handle open-source cloud implementation, and understand risks involved in cloud computing.

This information pertains to the Course Structure for ADDO7023: Game Theory for Data Science.
What are the prerequisites for ADDO7023?
The prerequisites for ADDO7023 include Probability and Algebra.
What are the course objectives of ADDO7023?

The course objectives of ADDO7023 are: 1. To introduce the student to the notion of a game, its solutions concepts, and other basic notions and tools of game theory, and the main applications for which they are appropriate, including electronic trading markets. 2. To formalize the notion of strategic thinking and rational choice by using the tools of game theory, and to provide insights into using game theory in modeling applications. 3. To draw the connections between game theory, computer science, and economics, especially emphasizing the computational issues. 4. To introduce contemporary topics in the intersection of game theory, computer science, and economics. 5. To apply game theory in searching, auctioning, and trading.
Can you list the course outcomes of ADDO7023?

The course outcomes of ADDO7023 are: 1. Analyze and Discuss the notion of a strategic game and equilibria and identify the characteristics of the main applications of these concepts. 2. Discuss the use of Nash Equilibrium for other problems. Identify key strategic aspects and based on these be able to connect them to appropriate game theoretic concepts given a real-world situation. 3. Identify some applications that need aspects of Bayesian Games. Implement a typical Virtual Business scenario using Game theory. 4. Identify and discuss the working principle of Non-Cooperative Games. 5. Discuss the Mechanism for Design Aggregating Preferences. 6. Identify and discuss the working principle: Repeated Games.
What is covered in the 'Introduction' module of ADDO7023?

The 'Introduction' module covers topics such as making rational choices, basics of Games, strategy, preferences, payoffs, mathematical basics, game theory, rational choice, basic solution concepts, non-cooperative versus cooperative games, basic computational issues, finding equilibria, and learning in games. It also covers typical application areas for game theory like Google’s sponsored search, eBay auctions, and electricity trading markets.

Demonstrating project management principles during project work.
How are project topics selected and allocated in ADP701?

Project topics in ADP701 are selected and allocated based on defined processes. These processes include project orientation at the end of the sixth semester, informing students about relevant domains and domain experts, recommending literature from reputed conferences/journals, selecting large and real-time datasets, encouraging unique project ideas, and finalizing topics based on novelty, technology used, and relevance.
What is the format of the project report in ADP701?

The project report in ADP701 should contain various sections such as abstract, introduction, literature survey, problem statement and objectives, proposed system, analysis/framework/algorithm, design details, methodology, experimental setup, database details, performance evaluation parameters, software and hardware setup, implementation plan, timeline chart, and references. Certification courses for relevant technical skill sets may also be suggested.
How is the term work evaluated in ADP701?

How is the final project evaluation conducted in ADP701?

The final project evaluation in ADP701 includes oral and practical examinations conducted by internal and external examiners approved by the University of Mumbai at the end of the semester. Evaluation parameters include the quality of problem selected, clarity of problem definition and feasibility of solution, relevance to specialization/industrial trends, originality, clarity of objectives and scope, quality of analysis and design, quality of written and oral presentation, and assessment of individual as well as teamwork.

This information pertains to the Major Project (ADP801).
What are the objectives of ADP801?

The objectives of ADP801 are: 1. To acquaint with the process of identifying the needs and converting it into the problem. 2. To familiarize the process of solving the problem in a group. 3. To acquaint with the process of applying basic engineering fundamentals to attempt solutions to the problems. 4. To inculcate the process of self-learning and research.
What are the outcomes of ADP801?

The outcomes of ADP801 are: 1. Identify problems based on societal/research needs. 2. Apply knowledge and skill to solve societal problems in a group. 3. Draw the proper inferences from available results through theoretical/experimental/simulations. 4. Analyze the impact of solutions in societal and environmental context for sustainable development. 5. Demonstrate capabilities of self-learning in a group, which leads to lifelong learning. 6. Demonstrate project management principles during project work.
What are the guidelines for ADP801?

The guidelines for ADP801 include: 1. Internal guide has to keep track of the progress of the project and also has to maintain attendance report. This progress report can be used for awarding term work marks. 2. Project Report Format: At the end of semester, each group needs to prepare a project report as per the guidelines issued by the University of Mumbai. Report should be submitted in hardcopy. Also, each group should submit softcopy of the report along with project documentation, implementation code, required utilities, software and user Manuals. A project report should preferably contain at least following details: Abstract, Introduction, Literature Survey/Existing system, Limitation Existing system or research gap, Problem Statement and Objective, Proposed System, Analysis/Framework/Algorithm, Design details, Methodology (your approach to solve the problem) Proposed System, Experimental Set up, Details of Database or details about input to systems or selected data, Performance Evaluation Parameters (for Validation), Software and Hardware Setup, Results and Discussion, Conclusion and Future Work,
